A 'sway bar' or 'anti-roll bar' or 'stabilizer bar' is a part of an automobile
suspension that helps reduce the body roll of a vehicle during fast cornering or
over road irregularities. It connects opposite (left/right) wheels together
through short lever arms linked by a torsion spring. A sway bar increases the
suspension's roll stiffnessâits resistance to roll in turns, independent of its
spring rate in the vertical direction. The first stabilizer bar patent was
awarded to the Canadian S. L. C. Coleman of Fredericton, New Brunswick on April
22, 1919. Mario Theriault, Great Maritime Inventions 1833-1950, Goose Lane
Editions, 2001, p. 69
